pageData.text: , one of the unifying theories of geology, is the idea that Earth’s outer layer () is divided into large plates that move on top of the . This laboratory is designed to help students understand the basic mechanics of how the plates move, recognize characteristic features (volcanoes, , mountains, etc.) that form in response to plate movement, and quantify plate movement over time. Students will begin the laboratory by examining the observational evidence that led Alfred Wegener to propose continental drift. Then students will explore the relationship between volcano and seismic data to determine the location of plate boundaries using Google Earth Pro. During the virtual field trip, students will be introduced to each type of and the features that are associated with them. Finally, students will examine paleomagnetic and track data to determine the rate and direction of movement over geological time.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 10 minutes 
Activity 1: Exploring Tectonic Plate Boundaries with Google Earth Pro – 45 minutes 
Activity 2: Calculating Seafloor Spreading Rates from Paleomagnetic Data – 45 minutes 
Activity 3: Tracking Pacific Plate Movement via the Hawaiian Hot Spot – 45 minutes

text: Demonstrate a knowledge and understanding of continental drift and the different lines of evidence that Alfred Wegener used to support his theory.
Identify the different types of plate boundaries and the characteristic features that form at them because of tectonic plate movement.
Differentiate between oceanic and continental crust, and identify the <button class='glossary-text'>plate boundary</button> settings where oceanic crust is created or recycled.
Describe the relationship between age and the topography of the ocean floor relative to plate boundaries.
Calculate the rate of tectonic plate movement through the interpretation of paleomagnetic data at ( rate), tracking, and continuity of structures.

pageData.text: Iceland’s Thingvellir National Park provides visitors with the opportunity to stand on a divergent boundary as two continents slowly pull away from each other.  Iceland is a volcanically active island and is made up of <button class='glossary-text'>lithosphere</button> from the North American and Eurasian plates. These two plates are being pushed apart as new crust forms at the mid-Atlantic ridge deep in the Atlantic Ocean. This <button class='glossary-text'>plate boundary</button> continues underneath Iceland, causing the overlying crust to crack. Over the centuries, a canyon has been slowly forming in the national park with rock walls that get a little bit farther away from each other each year. Although the movement of the plates is very small, only about 1 cm a year, it can still be observed by how it shapes the overlying rocks. For instance, a walking path over one part of the continental divide recently collapsed as the crust buckled, opening a deep chasm in the rocks under the path and requiring a new bridge to be built. Because the area sits over the plate boundary, it is also highly geothermically active with hot spring geysers and provides scientists with an opportunity to study the effects of crust changes that would ordinarily require a deep ocean visit.

Þingvellir National Park in Iceland, where the North American and Eurasian tectonic plates meet by sikeri is available under CC BY 2.0 at
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:%C3%9Eingvellir_National_Park_in_Iceland,_where_the_North_American_and_Eurasian_tectonic_plates_meet_%2826153584629%29_%282%29.jpg

pageData.altText: A bridge between two rock walls and suspended over a continental divide.

pageData.text: In the early 1960s, the emergence of the theory of started a revolution in the earth sciences and began shaping our understanding of the dynamic planet upon which we live. Plate tectonics explains the outer layer of Earth as a group of separate plates that move with respect to each other and change Earth’s surface as they move. We now know that, directly or indirectly, plate tectonics influences nearly all geologic processes. It has provided explanations to questions such as why earthquakes and volcanic eruptions occur in very specific areas around the world, and how and why great mountain ranges like the Alps and Himalayas formed.

At first it was difficult for scientists to accept the idea that Earth’s oceans, continents, and mountain chains are only temporary features that move and change over time, as the changes occur at such a slow rate that they are not easily detected. Over time, as technological advancements facilitated the mapping of the ocean floor and the radiometric dating of rocks, the idea that continents break apart and ocean basins open and close became the standard belief among geoscientists. Decades of evidence proves that tectonic processes have been operating on Earth for billions of years. In this laboratory, you will explore the evidence and the geologic reasoning that led to the development of the modern <button class='glossary-text'>plate-tectonic theory</button>.

pageData.subTitle: Continental Drift Hypothesis
pageData.text: In 1912, Alfred Wegener, a German meteorologist and explorer, began writing papers detailing his . Wegener hypothesized that approximately 225 million years ago, all the continents were joined together to form a single landmass, or supercontinent, which he called Pangaea, and that since then, the continents have drifted to their present-day locations (Figure 1). While Wegener was not the first to propose that the continents had moved to their present-day locations over time, his work in support of the idea was the most comprehensive as he detailed five lines of evidence to support his continental drift hypothesis.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram showing Earth’s land mass(es) as Pangaea, Laurasis and Gondwana, and in the modern world

pageData.text:
1. Puzzle-like Fit of Africa and South America Coastlines
    Wegener’s first line of evidence was that the Atlantic coastlines of Africa and South America seemed to match, almost like puzzle pieces. He proposed that these continents were at one time a single continent that drifted apart over time. Wegener noticed that when he put the continental puzzle pieces together, other things started to match and fit together.

1. Matching Rock Formations in Africa and South America
    Wegener noted that the same igneous rock types were found on both South America and Africa. Decades later, geoscientists radiometrically dated the rocks and found the rock units were the same ages, which indicates that when the rock formed, the continents of South America and Africa were joined.

1. Matching Mountain Ranges
    Wegener observed the continuity of mountain ranges, noting that mountain chains of similar ages aligned when the continents are moved back into Pangaea positions. The oldest portions of the Appalachian Mountains, extending from the northeastern United States through eastern Canada, match up with the Caledonides of Ireland, Britain, Greenland, and Scandinavia. A younger part of the Appalachians lined up with a belt in Africa and Europe.

1. Matching Fossil Evidence
    Wegener postulated that if the African and South American continents were joined together as a supercontinent at one time, they would have had similar climates and should have been inhabited by the same plants and animals. Wegener found the fossil remains of the Mesosaurus, a small freshwater reptile from the Permian Period in both southern Brazil and in South Africa. He also found fossils of the Glossopteris, an ancient woody fern, in matching areas of southern Africa, South America, Australia, India, and Antarctica. The same fossils occur in Africa, India, Australia, and South America and form definite patterns (shown by the bands of colors in Figure 2) and provide strong evidence that these regions were once contiguous.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing where the same fossils occur in Africa, Antarctica, India, Australia, and South America and that definite patterns are formed (shown by the yellow, brown, green, and blue color bands), which provides strong evidence that these regions were once contiguous.

pageData.text:
1. Matching Glacial Deposits
    As glacial ice moves, it cuts grooves and scratches into the underlying rocks and produces folds and mounds in soft sediments. These features provide evidence of not only the extent of glaciation but also the direction the ice was moving during glaciation. Wegener found glacial deposits of the same age (Permian-Carboniferous) in South America, Africa, Australia, and India, which he suggested would not have existed if the continents had not been joined together at one point in time.

text: However, even with these lines of evidence, very few scientists supported Wegener’s because he was unable to explain how continents could move.

pageData.question: Which of the following was NOT one of the lines of evidence described by Wegener in support of his continental drift hypothesis?

options.text: All continental land masses are composed of the same type of rock.
Glacial deposits of the same age have been found across several continents.
The Atlantic coastlines of Africa and South America seem to fit like puzzle pieces.
Some mountain ranges align between continents when arranged into Pangaea positions.
Fossils from the same prehistoric species have been found across several continents.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Although the composition of the land masses differs, matching igneous rock formations were found on both South America and Africa, suggesting that when this rock formed, the continents were joined.

pageData.question: Wegener proposed that the continents were once a single land mass, which he called Pangaea. Which of the following would some of the continents have had in common when they were joined together?

options.text: climate
elevation
density
length of coastline
earthquake frequency

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Wegener postulated that if the continents were joined together as a supercontinent at one time, they would have had similar climates and should have been inhabited by the same plants and animals.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In 1912, Alfred Wegener, a German meteorologist and explorer, began writing papers detailing his continental drift hypothesis. Wegener hypothesized that approximately 225 million years ago, all the continents were joined together to form a single landmass, or supercontinent, which he called Pangaea, and that since then, the continents have drifted to their present-day locations. While Wegener was not the first to propose that the continents had moved to their present-day locations over time, his work in support of the idea was the most comprehensive as he detailed five lines of evidence to support his continental drift hypothesis.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Wegener’s first line of evidence was that the Atlantic coastlines of Africa and South America seemed to match, almost like puzzle pieces. He proposed that these continents were at one time a single continent that drifted apart over time. Wegener noticed that when he put the continental puzzle pieces together, other things started to match and fit together. He noted that the same igneous rock types were found on both South America and Africa, which suggests the continents were joined when the rock formed. He also observed the continuity of mountain ranges, noting that mountain chains of similar ages aligned when the continents are moved back into Pangaea positions. Wegener also postulated that if the African and South American continents were joined together as a supercontinent at one time, they should have been inhabited by the same plants and animals. This was supported by the discovery of fossils of the same prehistoric species across several continents. Finally, Wegener observed glacial deposits of the same age across several continents that would not have existed if the continents had not been joined together at one point in time.

pageData.subTitle: Scientific Discovery and Rise of Plate-Tectonic Theory
pageData.text: Beginning in the 1950s, new evidence emerged to revive the debate about Wegener’s ideas and their implications. In particular, four major scientific developments spurred the formulation of the : (1) demonstration of the ruggedness and youth of the ocean floor; (2) confirmation of repeated reversals of Earth’s magnetic field in the geologic past; (3) emergence of the seafloor-spreading hypothesis and associated recycling of oceanic crust; and (4) precise documentation that the world’s earthquake and volcanic activity is concentrated along and submarine mountain ranges.

pageData.subTitle: Ocean Floor Mapping
pageData.text: Before the 19th century, the depths of the open ocean were largely a matter of speculation, and most people thought that the ocean floor was relatively flat and featureless. Our picture of the ocean floor greatly sharpened after World War I (1914–18), when primitive sonar systems began to measure ocean depth by recording the time it took for a sound signal (commonly an electrically generated ping) from the ship to bounce off the ocean floor and return. Time graphs of the returned signals revealed that the ocean floor was much more rugged than previously thought. Such time measurements led to the discovery of a great underwater mountain range that virtually encircled Earth. Called the , this immense submarine mountain chain—more than 50,000 kilometers (km) long and, in places, more than 800 km across—zigzags between the continents, winding its way around the globe like the seam on a baseball.

Rising an average of about 4,500 meters (m) above the seafloor, the <button class='glossary-text'>mid-ocean ridge</button> overshadows all the mountains in the United States except for Denali in Alaska (6,194 m). Though hidden beneath the ocean surface, the global mid-ocean ridge system is the most prominent topographic feature on the surface of our planet.

pageData.subTitle: Paleomagnetism
pageData.text: Invisible lines of magnetism arc out through space from the South Magnetic Pole, travel around the outside of the earth at its equator, then arc back into the North Magnetic Pole to form Earth’s magnetic field. Magnetic compass needles are attracted to the magnetic North Pole, which is located in the Arctic Islands of Northern Canada, about 700 km from the geographic North Pole.

In the 1950s, geologists learned that tiny crystals of iron-rich minerals, such as magnetite (Fe3O4), acquire and retain the directional signature of Earth’s magnetic field when they form. This happens when volcanic lava cools and crystalizes below the Curie Point (~580° C). This ancient magnetism is called . When geologists first started detecting paleomagnetism in layers of cooled lava (volcanic rock) stacked one atop the other, they discovered that Earth’s magnetic field has not always been the same. It has undergone periodic reversals. During times of the north-seeking compass needle (and tiny iron-bearing mineral crystals in volcanic rock) points in the direction of Earth’s present magnetic north pole. But during times of , the north-seeking end of the compass needle points in the opposite direction (geographic south). Figure 3 illustrates the earth’s magnetic field in a time of normal polarity and shows the difference between the earth’s magnetic axis and the rotation axis.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Magnetic and geographic poles of Earth demonstrating normal polarity, when the north-seeking compass needle points toward the current magnetic pole, and reversed polarity, when the north-seeking compass needle points toward the geographic south

pageData.text: Magnetic anomalies are deviations from the average strength of the magnetic field in a given area. Areas of higher than normal strength are and areas of less than average strength are . In the late 1950s, the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey scanned the ocean for marine magnetic anomalies and discovered that the rocks of the seafloor contained alternating striped patterns of positive and negative magnetic anomalies, called . As more of the seafloor was mapped, the magnetic variations turned out not to be random or isolated occurrences but instead revealed recognizable patterns. When these magnetic patterns were mapped over a wide region, the ocean floor showed a zebra-like pattern (Figure 4). Alternating stripes of magnetically different rock were laid out in rows on either side of the : one stripe with normal polarity and the adjoining stripe with reversed polarity.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram showing the mapped magnetic patterns of the ocean floor resulting in a zebra-like pattern in three time periods: a. the spreading ridge about 5 million years ago; b. about 2 to 3 million years ago; and c. present-day. Alternating stripes of magnetically different rock are laid out in rows on either side of a mid-ocean ridge: one stripe with normal polarity and the adjoining stripe with reversed polarity.

pageData.text: Image courtesy of the U.S. Geological Survey.

The symmetrical pattern of the on the seafloor rocks is the result of two processes: the formation of seafloor (lava cooling) and the reversals of Earth’s magnetic field. As volcanoes erupt along a , the lava cools below the Curie Point and records the reversals of Earth’s paleomagnetic field. Rocks formed during times of now have magnetic signatures that add to the modern field strength and create a , while rocks formed during times of have magnetic signatures that oppose the modern field and create a . The symmetrical pattern of paleomagnetic stripes developed as new crust was formed and magnetized and older crust moved down and spread away from both sides of the ridge under the influence of gravity in a process called .

pageData.subTitle: Seafloor Spreading
pageData.text: In 1962, Harry Hess outlined the basics of how seafloor spreading works: molten rock (magma) oozes up from the earth’s interior along the mid-ocean ridges, creating new seafloor that spreads away from the active ridge crest and, eventually, sinks into the deep <button class='glossary-text'>oceanic trenches</button>.

Hess supported his hypothesis with 3 lines of evidence: (1) at or near the crest of the ridge, the rocks are very young, and they become progressively older away from the ridge crest; (2) the youngest rocks at the ridge crest always have present-day (normal) polarity; and (3) stripes of rock parallel to the ridge crest alternate in magnetic polarity (normal-reversed-normal, etc.), suggesting that Earth’s magnetic field has flip-flopped many times. By explaining both the zebra-like magnetic striping and the construction of the mid-ocean ridge system, the seafloor spreading hypothesis quickly gained converts and represented another major advance in the development of the . Furthermore, the oceanic crust now came to be appreciated as a natural “tape recording” of the history of the reversals in Earth’s magnetic field.

Hess suggested that new oceanic crust continuously spread away from the ridges in a conveyor belt–like motion. Many millions of years later, the oceanic crust eventually descended into the oceanic <button class='glossary-text'>trenches</button>—very deep, narrow canyons along the rim of the Pacific Ocean basin. According to Hess, the Atlantic Ocean was expanding while the Pacific Ocean was shrinking. As old oceanic crust was consumed in the trenches, new magma rose and erupted along the spreading ridges to form new crust. In effect, the ocean basins were perpetually being “recycled,” with the creation of new crust and the destruction of old oceanic <button class='glossary-text'>lithosphere</button> occurring simultaneously. Thus, Hess’s ideas explained why the earth does not get bigger with seafloor spreading, why there is so little sediment accumulation on the ocean floor, and why oceanic rocks are much younger than continental rocks.

Hess reasoned that the sediment has been accumulating for about 300 million years at most. This interval is approximately the time needed for the ocean floor to move from the ridge crest to the trenches, where oceanic crust descends into the and is destroyed. Meanwhile, magma is continually rising along the , where the “recycling” process is completed by the creation of new oceanic crust. This recycling of the seafloor also explained why the oldest fossils found on the seafloor are no more than about 180 million years old. In contrast, marine fossils in rock strata on land—some of which are found high in the Himalayas, over 8,500 m above sea level—can be considerably older. Hess’s ideas also resolved a question that plagued Wegener’s theory of continental drift: how do the continents move? Wegener had a vague notion that the continents must simply “plow” through the ocean floor, which his critics rightly argued was physically impossible. With , the continents did not have to push through the ocean floor but were carried along as the ocean floor spread from the ridges.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements is true about Earth’s magnetism?

options.text: The polarity of its magnetic field reverses periodically over time.
Evidence of magnetic anomalies form distinct patterns in Earth’s atmosphere.
Although it provides evidence of paleomagnetism, sea floor spreading does support the continental drift hypothesis.
Magnetic compass needles are attracted to the magnetic South Pole.
Paleomagnetic stripes are random isolated occurrences.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Earth’s magnetic field has undergone periodic reversals in polarity. During times of normal polarity, magnetic compass needles are attracted to the magnetic North Pole. These reversals are observable in the regular pattern of paleomagnetic stripes on the ocean floor formed by the process of sea floor spreading, one of the mechanisms of continental drift.

pageData.question: During times of reversed polarity, which of the following events would you expected to happen?

options.text: Magnetic compass needles point south.
Magnetic compass needles point north.
The rate of sea floor spreading slows.
The rate of sea floor spreading quickens.
Sea floor rocks lose their magnetism.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: During times of reversed polarity, the north-seeking end of the compass needle points in the opposite direction (geographic south).

pageData.subTitle: Mapping Seismic Data to Locate Concentrations of Earthquakes
pageData.text: The study of global seismicity greatly advanced with the establishment of the Worldwide Standardized Seismograph Network (WWSSN) to monitor the compliance of the 1963 treaty banning above-ground testing of nuclear weapons. The improved data from the WWSSN instruments allowed seismologists to map precisely the zones of earthquake concentration worldwide. The use of seismographs, earthquake-recording instruments, worldwide enabled scientists to learn that earthquakes tend to be concentrated in certain areas, most notably along the <button class='glossary-text'>oceanic trenches</button> and spreading ridges. Seismologists were beginning to identify several prominent earthquake zones parallel to the <button class='glossary-text'>trenches</button> that typically were inclined 40–60° from the horizontal and extended several hundred kilometers into the earth. The recognition of such a connection helped confirm the seafloor-spreading hypothesis by pinpointing the zones where Hess had predicted oceanic crust is being generated (along the ridges) and the zones where oceanic <button class='glossary-text'>lithosphere</button> sinks back into the mantle (beneath the trenches).

pageData.subTitle: The Plate-Tectonic Theory
pageData.text: Based on the data outlined, a collection of scientists devised the , a theory that the earth’s lithosphere is broken into dozens of plates that move on the plastic, . Over time, the plates are created and destroyed. The interactions between the plates cause earthquakes and create major features on the continents and ocean basins, such as volcanoes, mountain belts, ocean ridges, and trenches. The basic concepts of the theory include the following:

text: Earth’s crust and the uppermost part of the mantle form a rigid outermost layer called the lithosphere that extends to a depth of 100 to 150 km. The lithosphere is not a single shell but is broken into large pieces called .

There are two types of lithosphere: continental and oceanic. Continental lithosphere is thicker and less dense than oceanic lithosphere. The difference in density is the reason why only oceanic lithosphere is subducted.

<button class='glossary-text'>Continental margins</button> are defined as locations on a plate where the landmass (continent) meets the oceanic lithosphere. There are two types of continental margins: active and passive. <button class='glossary-text'>Active continental margins</button> are located on or adjacent to a <button class='glossary-text'>plate boundary</button> and feature a narrow continental shelf and steep continental slope, while <button class='glossary-text'>passive continental margins</button> are far from a plate boundary and feature a wide continental shelf and a gentle continental slope. The west coast of the United States is an example of an active continental margin, while the east coast is a passive continental margin.

The lithospheric plates rest on the asthenosphere, a zone in the upper mantle that, although solid, has a low rigidity that allows it to flow like a soft plastic. The asthenosphere is the lubricant that facilitates plate movement. Plates move relative to one another at a rate of 1 to 15 cm/year, which is roughly equivalent to the growth rate of human fingernails.

A is where 2 plates make contact. In some locations, 3 plates come together; these locations are called . Plate boundaries are defined and identified by mapping narrow belts of earthquakes, volcanoes, and young mountain ranges. The earth is made up of a dozen or so major plates and several minor plates (Figure 5). Plate boundaries are represented by the black lines. Most plates are part continental and part oceanic . There are 3 different kinds of plate boundaries, defined by the relative motions of the adjacent plates.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Illustration showing the boundaries of the major and minor plates of the earth represented by black lines

pageData.text: 1. form where plates move away from one another at the axis of submarine mountain ranges called . Molten magma rises from the to form new oceanic lithosphere at the ridge axis. The ocean grows wider through this process, called . Seafloor spreading pushes older oceanic lithosphere toward the continents (Figure 6).

pageData.altText: Figure 6: A divergent plate boundary identifying the magma rising and forming new oceanic lithosphere with arrows moving outward from the ridge axis.

pageData.text: 1. form where plates move toward each other, and the oceanic of one plate sinks (subducted plate) into the mantle below the other plate (overriding plate) at . The overriding plate may comprise either oceanic or continental lithosphere. If both plates involved are composed of oceanic lithosphere, the older plate will be subducted because it has an increased density due to a longer cooling period. The boundary at a subduction zone forms a . As the subducting plate is pulled toward the mantle, steam is released. The steam lowers the melting point of the rock in the overriding plate, producing magma. The magma rises to the surface to produce volcanoes as part of either a (like the Japanese islands) or a (like the Andes Mountains), where the overriding plate is continental lithosphere (Figure 7).Since continental lithosphere is too buoyant to “sink” into the mantle, when subduction consumes all of an oceanic plate between two continents, a is formed. Collision zones feature like the Himalayas. Folding during the collision thickens the crust to the extent that the thickest continental crust is found under collisional mountain belts.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Illustration of collision zone with collisional mountain belts, where folding during the collision thickens the crust to the extent that the thickest continental crust is found under collisional mountain belts

pageData.text: 1. form when two plates slide past one another along a vertical fracturing zone called a . Most transform faults break the into segments and are also called oceanic fracture zones. A few, such as the San Andreas Fault, cut through continental plates on a large enough scale to be considered a . are locations where continental is stretched and thinned to the breaking point. If rifting is successful, a continent splits into 2 pieces separated by a new oceanic plate, which gradually widens due to .Plate boundaries shift and change through time. In the tectonic cycle, new oceanic lithosphere created at the oceanic ridges is pushed away from the ridges during seafloor spreading and is returned to the mantle at .

pageData.altText: Figure 8: A transform plate boundary, showing two plates sliding past each other with arrows pointing in opposite directions and Earthquakes occurring on the plate boundary axis.

pageData.question: The rate at which tectonic plates move relative to one another is most like which of the following?

options.text: the growth rate of human fingernails
the growth rate of plant seedlings
the growth rate of human children
the average speed of vehicles on the highway
the top speed of an average human running

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Plates move relative to one another at a rate of 1 to 15 cm/year, which is roughly equivalent to the growth rate of human fingernails.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes how tectonic plates are able to move?

options.text: The plates rest on a layer of earth with high plasticity.
The plates float on a layer of liquid metal.
The plates are pulled apart by gravity over time.
The plates are pushed together as sea levels rise due to climate change.
The plates slide as changes in their density cause drastic elevation shifts.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The lithospheric plates rest on the asthenosphere, a zone in the upper mantle that, although solid, has a low rigidity that allows it to flow like a soft plastic. This layer is what facilitates plate movement.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Plates move relative to one another at a rate of 1 to 15 cm/year, which is roughly equivalent to the growth rate of human fingernails. A plate boundary is where 2 plates make contact. In some locations, 3 plates come together; these locations are called triple junctions. Plate boundaries are defined and identified by mapping narrow belts of earthquakes, volcanoes, and young mountain ranges. The lithospheric plates rest on the asthenosphere, a zone in the upper mantle that, although solid, has a low rigidity that allows it to flow like a soft plastic. The asthenosphere is the lubricant that facilitates plate movement. Divergent plate boundaries form where plates move away from one another at the axis of submarine mountain ranges called mid-ocean ridges. Convergent plate boundaries form where plates move toward each other, and the oceanic lithosphere of one plate sinks (subducted plate) into the mantle below the other plate (overriding plate) at subduction zones. Transform boundaries form when two plates slide past one another along a vertical fracturing zone called a transform fault.

img.alt: Figure 6: A divergent plate boundary identifying the magma rising and forming new oceanic lithosphere with arrows moving outward from the ridge axis.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Plates move relative to one another at a rate of 1 to 15 cm/year, which is roughly equivalent to the growth rate of human fingernails. A plate boundary is where 2 plates make contact. In some locations, 3 plates come together; these locations are called triple junctions. Plate boundaries are defined and identified by mapping narrow belts of earthquakes, volcanoes, and young mountain ranges. The lithospheric plates rest on the asthenosphere, a zone in the upper mantle that, although solid, has a low rigidity that allows it to flow like a soft plastic. The asthenosphere is the lubricant that facilitates plate movement. Divergent plate boundaries form where plates move away from one another at the axis of submarine mountain ranges called mid-ocean ridges. Convergent plate boundaries form where plates move toward each other, and the oceanic lithosphere of one plate sinks (subducted plate) into the mantle below the other plate (overriding plate) at subduction zones. Transform boundaries form when two plates slide past one another along a vertical fracturing zone called a transform fault.

img.alt: Figure 6: A divergent plate boundary identifying the magma rising and forming new oceanic lithosphere with arrows moving outward from the ridge axis.

pageData.subTitle: Tracking Tectonic-Plate Movement
pageData.text: Plate motion can be measured as or absolute movement. Relative movement refers to the movement between two plates at a given point on the . For every pair of plates, their relative motion is defined by a direction and a rate. This movement has a magnitude of typically tens of millimeters per year. It is relative plate movement that determines the amount and type of earthquake and volcanic activity present along a plate boundary. Relative plate motion was first determined when geoscientists correlated marine magnetic anomalies and the paleomagnetic reversal chronology. The width of the magnetic anomaly provided a distance, and the age of reversal provided a timeline. Together, the information allowed geoscientists to determine a rate.

is the motion of a plate with respect to a fixed location. At first geoscientists tracked absolute plate motion by examining data. Hot spots are places within the mantle where rocks melt to generate magma. The magma generated by the hot spot rises through the rigid plates of the and produces active volcanoes at the earth’s surface. As oceanic volcanoes move away from the hot spot, they cool and subside, producing older islands, atolls, and seamounts. As continental volcanoes move away from the hot spot, they cool, subside, and become dormant and eventually extinct. The movement of the Pacific Plate over the fixed Hawaiian hot spot is illustrated with the formation of the Hawaiian Ridge-Emperor Seamount Chain (Figure 8).

pageData.altText: Figure 9: Illustration showing the movement of the Pacific Plate over the fixed Hawaiian hot spot, and thus the formation of the Hawaiian Ridge-Emperor Seamount Chain.

pageData.text: Map Data: Copyright 2023, Google Earth Pro

Today geologists track the current direction and rate of absolute plate motion using the Global Positioning System (GPS). The GPS satellite network includes 24 satellites that are currently in orbit 20,000 km above Earth as part of the NavStar system of the U.S. Department of Defense. These satellites continuously transmit radio signals back to Earth. To determine a precise position on Earth (longitude, latitude, elevation), triangulation is used. From any one position on Earth, one must simultaneously receive signals from at least four satellites, recording the exact time and location of each satellite when its signal was received. By repeatedly measuring distances between specific points, geologists can determine if there has been active movement between plates.

pageData.subTitle: Calculating Rate
pageData.text: Change and time are two of the main themes in the geosciences. Combined, this creates a rate: the rapidity in which change occurs. There are many rates in the geosciences—plate-tectonic velocities (distance over time), crystal growth rates (change in crystal size over time), river and groundwater discharge (volume change over time), decay rates (change in the number of parent isotopes over time), or any variable that is divided by time. This is represented mathematically by the following equation:

pageData.altText: Equation 1: Mathematical equation for determining rate, where rate equals the change in the variable (e.g., temperature, pressure, or distance) divided by the change in time

pageData.text: R is the rate, ΔX is the change in whatever you are looking at (it could be temperature, pressure, distance, or anything else) and Δt is the change in time. In mathematics and many science fields, Δ means “change.”

<button class='glossary-text'>Velocity</button> (change in position divided by time) is the most common type of rate calculated in the geosciences and is commonly expressed in kilometers per million years, centimeters per year, or millimeters per year. Most people have heard the expression “rate equals distance over time” (or the more accurate version, “velocity equals distance over time”). This can be written in equation form as:

pageData.altText: Mathematical equation for determining velocity, where velocity (or rate) equals distance divided by time

pageData.text: Here, d = distance, t = time, R = rate, and V = velocity. This is just a specific example of a rate because distance (d) is the change in position, ΔX.

text: Determine which changing variable is ΔX and which is Δt.
Calculate ΔX and Δt to determine the change in the variable(s).
Calculate the rate using ΔX and Δt.
Check to see what the units on your final number should be.
Evaluate your answer. Does that number seem reasonable?

pageData.question: According to the geosciences, a rate is a change in a variable over which of the following?

options.text: time
distance
change in volume
change in density
mass

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Rate is the change in a variable (I.e., temperature, pressure, distance) over the change in time. There are many different types of rates in the geosciences.

pageData.question: At 6 A.M. on a given day, the temperature outside is 12 °C. At noon, the temperature rises to 26 °C. The value “14” represents which of the following?

options.text: change in temperature
change in time
the rate
the initial temperature
the date

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This value represents the change in temperature, ΔX (26 °C -12 °C = 14 °C). The change in time, Δt, is 6 hours (12 – 6 = 6).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Change and time are two of the main themes in the geosciences. Combined, this creates a rate: the rapidity in which change occurs. There are many rates in the geosciences—plate-tectonic velocities (distance over time), crystal growth rates (change in crystal size over time), river and groundwater discharge (volume change over time), etc. This is represented mathematically by the following equation:R is the rate, ΔX is the change in whatever you are looking at (it could be temperature, pressure, distance, or anything else) and Δt is the change in time. In mathematics and many science fields, Δ means “change.”Steps for calculating a rate:
  1. Determine which changing variable is ΔX and which is Δt.
  2. Calculate ΔX and Δt to determine the change in the variable(s).
  3. Calculate the rate using ΔX and Δt.
  4. Check to see what the units on your final number should be.
  5. Evaluate your answer. Does that number seem reasonable?

img.alt: Equation 1: Mathematical equation for determining rate, where rate equals the change in the variable (e.g., temperature, pressure, or distance) divided by the change in time

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. To prepare, download Google Earth Pro and the Plate Tectonics Lab file. In Activity 1, open the file and observe the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. Next, observe the concentration of earthquakes. Then, measure the distance from Africa to South America. Next, calculate the rate of seafloor spreading. Then, compare the rate of sea floor spreading between Australia and Antarctica. Finally, observe the characteristics of types of plate boundaries. In Activity 2, print the map of plates and measure the length of the scale. Then, measure the distance across an anomaly and calculate its spreading rate. Repeat the last 2 steps for both plates on the map. Next, measure the distance to the furthest magnetic anomaly on the scale. Then, determine the age of the anomaly and calculate the spreading half rate. Next, calculate the total spreading rate. Repeat the last 4 steps for both ridges on the map. Then, continue to Activity 3.

A map of the procedural workflow for activity 3 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, you will print the elevation map. Then, you will measure the length of the scale. Next, you will measure the distance between volcanic centers. Then, you will calculate the rate of plate motion. Finally, repeat this activity until 4 different distances are measured.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Why was Alfred Wegner’s initial hypothesis about continental drift not supported by other scientists?

options.text: He was unable to explain how the continents could move.
There was not enough evidence that the continents had changed locations.
His hypothesis was contradicted by paleomagnetic evidence.
He was unable to explain why two different continents would have matching glacial deposits.
His hypothesis was contradicted by the discovery of the global mid-ocean ridge.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following was NOT used by Henry Hess as evidence for seafloor spreading?

options.text: The same fossilized organisms were found in parallel stripes on either side of the ridge.
Rocks become older as you move out from the ridge.
The youngest rocks at the ridge have present-day polarity.
Stripes of rock parallel to the ridge alternate in magnetic polarity.
All of these were used as evidence of seafloor spreading by Hess.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT true of lithospheric plates?

options.text: They are composed of Earth’s crust only.
They can be either oceanic or continental.
They extend to a depth of about 100 to 150 km.
They rest on the asthenosphere.
They come in contact at plate boundaries and triple junctions.

assestmentData.question: Where would you expect to find the youngest (most recently formed) sea floor?

options.text: at a mid-ocean ridge
in a stripe of reversed magnetic polarity
in a negative anomaly
in a deep ocean trench
closest to the north pole

assestmentData.question: The Himalayas are an example of which of the following structures?

options.text: a collision mountain belt
a volcanic island arc
a continental island arc
a transform plate boundary
a passive continental margin

assestmentData.question: The Hawaiian Island chain is the result of which type of tectonic phenomenon?

options.text: hot spot
divergent plate boundary
triple junction
continental rift
mid-ocean ridge

typeBefore.text: In this lab, you will explore the evidence that scientists used to develop the theory of .

You will need to install Google Earth Pro (GEP) on your computer and download the “PlateTectonicsLab Full.kmz” file. Google Earth Pro is a virtual globe application that allows you to explore, create, and analyze geographic information.

pageData.text: If you have not already, download Google Earth Pro.
Accept the agreement and download. You can enter Google Earth Pro from the desktop after installation.
If you have not already, download the “PlateTectonicsLab Full.kmz” file into a folder of your choice. Remember where you save it!
In Activity 1, you will use Google Earth Pro to explore tectonic plate boundaries by investigating maps of bathymetry, concentration of earthquakes, age of the ocean floor, and plate boundaries.

pages.title:
A
 Exploring Tectonic Plate Boundaries with Google Earth Pro (4 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Exploring Tectonic Plate Boundaries with Google Earth Pro (4 steps)

typeBefore.text: In this activity, you will explore the evidence that scientists used to develop the theory of and take a virtual tour of the features found at each type of tectonic .

pageData.text: Open Google Earth Pro.
*Google Earth Pro, Google,https://www.google.com/earth/about/
Turn off all irrelevant layers. In the Layers sidebar (bottom left), deselect the “Primary Database” box so that there are no labels or boundaries displayed on the virtual globe (Figure 10).

pageData.altText: Figure 10: Screenshot of Google Earth Pro showing the Layers drop-down menu with "3D Buildings" selected

pageData.text: Map Data: Copyright 2023, Google Earth Pro

To make terrain easier to see, increase the vertical exaggerate (makes the mountains taller and the valleys deeper). For a PC, from the menu bar click Tools > Options. For a Mac, click Google Earth Pro > Preferences. In the Terrain section (halfway down the window), enter a “3” in the “Elevation Exaggeration” field. Click “OK” (Figure 11).

pageData.altText: Figure 11: Screenshot of Google Earth Pro showing the Terrain settings

pageData.text: Map Data: Copyright 2023, Google Earth Pro

From the menu bar, click File > Open and locate the “PlateTectonicsLab Full.kmz” file. Select the file and select “Open”. In the Places sidebar (on the left), you should see “PlateTectonicsLab.kmz” (Figure 12). Expand it, if needed, by clicking on the small triangle to the left. Double-click on the first item, “1AB Mid-Atlantic Ocean Ridge”.

pageData.altText: Figure 12: Screenshot of Google Earth Pro showing the Places drop-down menu with the Platetectonics.kmz file selected

pageData.text: Map Data: Copyright 2023, Google Earth Pro

In GEP, examine the bathymetry of the Atlantic Ocean. The bottom of the GEP window gives the latitude, longitude, and elevation of the location of your cursor. Find the Mid-Atlantic Ridge and describe its shape. Is it closer to any one continent, or does it lie in the middle in the Atlantic Ocean?
How does the shape of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge compare to the coasts of the continents surrounding the Atlantic Ocean?

In the Places sidebar, double click the next item in the PlateTectonicsLab, “1C Mid-Atlantic Ocean Ridge Fracture”. Notice the numerous fractures running perpendicular to the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. Follow the fracture to the west to where it intersects the coast of South America, and then follow the fracture to the east to where it intersects with the coast of Africa. How does the location of these 2 intersections support the conclusion that South America and Africa once fit together (look at the shape of the coasts)?

In the Places sidebar, click on the little box to the left of “2 AB Earthquakes” to view all earthquakes recorded in 2010 by the United States Geological Survey (Figure 13). Note that to see all the earthquakes, you must zoom in (ctrl + shift + up arrow for PC, scroll with mouse or trackpad for Mac). Are there many earthquakes near ?

pageData.altText: Figure 13: Screenshot of Google Earth Pro showing the Places drop-down menu with " 2AB Earthquakes" selected

pageData.text: Map Data: Copyright 2023, Google Earth Pro
Along the mid-ocean ridges, are the earthquakes deep (greater than 60 km) or shallow (less than 60 km)? Click on an individual earthquake to see its depth.
Do more earthquakes occur on the edge or in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean? Do more earthquakes occur on the edge or in the middle of the Pacific Ocean?

While keeping the “2 AB Earthquakes” box selected, click on on the next item in the PlateTectonicsLab: “2C Japanese Earthquakes”. What major bathymetric feature is present near the string of earthquakes? You can view the area obliquely by holding “Shift + down arrow” to get a better 3-D perspective.

What is the approximate elevation of the ocean floor at “2C Japanese Earthquakes”? Is it deeper or more shallow than the floor closer to the Japanese islands? Is it deeper or more shallow than the floor to the southwest, further into the Pacific Ocean? Remember, the bottom of the GEP window gives the elevation of your cursor.

Deselect any selected layers. Then check the box next to “3 Ocean Crust Age”. GEP should now be displaying the color coded age of the ocean floor. What is the relationship between the ocean crust age and mid-ocean ridges?
What is the relationship between the ocean crust age at ocean <button class='glossary-text'>trenches</button> (like the one off the coast of Japan) and at mid-ocean ridges?
What does this imply about the movement of oceanic crust? How does this support the theory that oceanic crust is moving away from mid-ocean ridges and toward ocean trenches?
Double-click on “1C Mid-Atlantic Ocean Ridge Fracture” in the Places sidebar. Then, click on the check box next to this layer to display the yellow thumbtack on the map.

Determine the age of the crust at the end of the fracture (the crust closest to the coast of either Africa or South America) by comparing the color of the seafloor with the key in GEP (Figure 14). You can follow the fracture by looking at how the age of the ocean floor is shifted along the fracture (Figure 15).

image.altText: Figure 14: a color-coded scale showing the age of the ocean floor (in millions of years)

Figure 15: A color-coded image from Google Earth showing the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Ridge fracture in bands of colors ranging from shades of yellow to orange to red to depict the age of the ocean floor as it shifts

altText: a color-coded scale showing the age of the ocean floor (in millions of years)
A color-coded image from Google Earth showing the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Ridge fracture in bands of colors ranging from shades of yellow to orange to red to depict the age of the ocean floor as it shifts

pageData.text: Map Data: Copyright 2023, Google Earth Pro

In GEP, select the Ruler Tool (Tools > Ruler). Measure the distance from South America to Africa along the fracture path specified by the yellow thumbtack. Calculate the rate of spreading in cm/year. This will be the distance in centimeters (cm) divided by the age of the crust.

To measure a distance on the map, click a spot on the map with the cursor. Then, click a second spot on the map. A yellow line will appear between the two selected points and the Ruler window will show the distance. The units of measurement can be changed by selecting different units from the drop-down (Figure 16).

pageData.altText: Figure 16: Screenshot of Google Earth Pro showing the Ruler dialog box with the Mouse navigation field checked

pageData.text: Map Data: Copyright 2023, Google Earth Pro

Using the same method, pick a point between Australia and Antarctica along the ocean ridge and determine if Australia and Antarctica are moving away from each other faster or slower than South America and Africa. What is the rate at which the crust between Australia and Antarctica is spreading in cm/year?

In the Layers sidebar, deselect any selected layers and select “Plate Boundaries,” “2AB Earthquakes,” and “Global Volcanism Program - Holocene Volcanoes”. This last layer shows the earth’s tectonic plate boundaries and names, as well as earthquake activity and volcano locations.

Fly to each of the locations in Data Table 1 by entering the latitude and longitude coordinates listed into the Search field in the top left sidebar (Figure 17). You may need to select the triangle next to “Search” to expand this feature. Once you reach each location, zoom out to get a wider perspective on this location relative to nearby plate boundaries.

pageData.altText: Figure 17: Screenshot of Google Earth Pro showing the search bar for location coordinates

pageData.text: Map Data: Copyright 2023, Google Earth Pro
Determine which type of plate boundary is located at each location and record it in Data Table 1. Be specific—if convergent, identify the types of crust involved.

pageData.altText: Figure 18: Color codes for the plate boundary lines.

pageData.text: Then identify several of the characteristic features present at the boundary (earthquakes, volcanic arc, , trench, ridge, etc.), and record your data in Data Table 1.
In Activity 2, you will use a map of paleomagnetic data to calculate the rate of sea floor spreading on the Pacific, Cocos and Nazca plates.

pages.title:
A
 Calculating Seafloor Spreading Rates from Paleomagnetic Data (10 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Calculating Seafloor Spreading Rates from Paleomagnetic Data (10 steps)

pageData.text: If you have not already, print Figure 19. There are three on the map: Pacific plate, Cocos plate, and Nazca plate. The black double lines shown in the diagram indicate the East Pacific Rise (EPR). The colored areas represent the paleomagnetic anomalies (“stripes”). The ages of these anomalies are shown in the key at the top of the diagram, and a scale of 500 kilometers is shown at the bottom of the diagram.

pageData.altText: Figure 19: A map showing three lithospheric plates: Pacific plate, Cocos plate, and Nazca plate. The black double lines indicate the East Pacific Rise (EPR). The colored areas represent the paleomagnetic anomalies (“stripes”).

pageData.text: Data for figure was provided by the International Ocean Drilling Project (IODP).
With your ruler, measure and record the length of the 500-km scale in centimeters in the Lab Notebook.

With the ruler, measure the distance across each anomaly in centimeters and record it in Data Table 2 as “Ruler Distance.” Measure along the A line for the Cocos-Nazca plate and the B line for the Pacific-Nazca plate.
Calculate the distance across each anomaly in kilometers and record it in Data Table 2.
Distance across anomaly = ruler distance 500-km scale length ∗ 500
Convert the distance in kilometers to centimeters, and record the value in Data Table 2. There are 100,000 centimeters in a kilometer.
Calculate the spreading rates in centimeters/year (cm/year) for the magnetic anomalies. Use the duration of the anomaly for the number of years, and record it in Data Table 2.

In Figure 20, the diagrams labeled “South Atlantic Ridge” and “East Pacific Rise” show the distribution of crustal ages around two spreading ridges and the age of magnetic anomalies. The diagrams show the age patterns on one side of each ridge axis.

pageData.altText: Figure 20: Paleomagnetic data for the South Atlantic Ridge and East Pacific Rise. The diagrams show the distribution of crustal ages around two spreading ridges and the age of magnetic anomalies along with the age patterns on one side of each ridge axis

pageData.text: Record the distance from the spreading center to the farthest magnetic anomaly stripe in each ocean, and determine the age of that anomaly in millions of years (myr).
Calculate spreading half rates (in km/myr) for each ridge. Divide the kilometers by the age of the anomaly.
Determine the total spreading rate for each in km/myr. This will be double the half rates from Step 9.
In Activity 3, you will use elevation maps of the Hawaiian Islands to calculate the rate of plate motion for the Pacific plate over the Hawaiian .

pages.title:
A
 Tracking Pacific Plate Movement via the Hawaiian Hot Spot (6 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Tracking Pacific Plate Movement via the Hawaiian Hot Spot (6 steps)

typeBefore.text: The Hawaiian Islands, located in the Pacific Ocean far from the nearest oceanic ridge, are an excellent example of volcanic islands (Figure 21). Volcanoes on Kauai, Oahu, and Maui have erupted for millions of years, but the island of Hawaii hosts five huge volcanoes, one of which (Kilauea) has been active for the past 31 years. In addition, a new volcano, Loihi, is growing on the Pacific Ocean floor just south-east of Kilauea. As the Pacific Plate moves, Kilauea will become extinct and Loihi will be the primary active volcano.

typeBefore.altText: Figure 21: Chart showing the Hawaiian hot spot track. The arrows indicate locations where basalt samples were collected for radiometric dating. The radiometric dates are provided in millions of years.

pageData.text: If you have not already, print Figure 21.
Use a ruler to draw a line connecting each volcano center (tip of arrow). Connect Hawaii to Maui, Maui to Molokai, Molokai to Oahu, and Oahu to Kauai.
With your ruler, measure and record the length of the 50-km scale in the upper right corner of Figure 20 in centimeters.
Measure the distance between the volcanic centers of the Hawaiian Islands using a ruler, and record the ruler distance in Data Table 3.
Distance between volcanic centers = ruler distance 50-km scale length ∗ 50

Calculate the number of years of plate motion. In Figure 20, the number at each arrow pointing to a volcano is its age in millions of years (myr). Subtract the age of the younger volcano from the older volcano to find the number of years of plate motion, and record the value in Data Table 3.
Calculate the rate of plate motion (distance between volcanic centers divided by number of years of plate motion). Record your answers in Data Table 3.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.content: Investigation Overview
Google Earth Pro
PlateTectonicsLabFull.kmz file
Printable Figure 19
Printable Figure 21
Figure 1. Continental drift
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram showing Earth’s land mass(es) as Pangaea, Laurasis and Gondwana, and in the modern world

pageData.content: Figure 2. Fossil evidence for continental drift
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing where the same fossils occur in Africa, Antarctica, India, Australia, and South America and that definite patterns are formed (shown by the yellow, brown, green, and blue color bands), which provides strong evidence that these regions were once contiguous.

pageData.content: Figure 3. Earth’s magnetic field
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Magnetic and geographic poles of Earth demonstrating normal polarity, when the north-seeking compass needle points toward the current magnetic pole, and reversed polarity, when the north-seeking compass needle points toward the geographic south

pageData.content: Figure 4. Paleomagnetic stripes and seafloor spreading
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram showing the mapped magnetic patterns of the ocean floor resulting in a zebra-like pattern in three time periods: a. the spreading ridge about 5 million years ago; b. about 2 to 3 million years ago; and c. present-day. Alternating stripes of magnetically different rock are laid out in rows on either side of a mid-ocean ridge: one stripe with normal polarity and the adjoining stripe with reversed polarity.

pageData.content: Figure 5. Lithospheric plates
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Illustration showing the boundaries of the major and minor plates of the earth represented by black lines

pageData.content: Figure 6. Three types of plate boundaries
pageData.altText: Figure 6: A divergent plate boundary identifying the magma rising and forming new oceanic lithosphere with arrows moving outward from the ridge axis.

pageData.content: Figure 7. Subduction of an oceanic plate
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Illustration of collision zone with collisional mountain belts, where folding during the collision thickens the crust to the extent that the thickest continental crust is found under collisional mountain belts

pageData.content: Figure 8. The Hawaiian hot spot
pageData.altText: Figure 8: A transform plate boundary, showing two plates sliding past each other with arrows pointing in opposite directions and Earthquakes occurring on the plate boundary axis.

pageData.content: Equation 1. Rate of change
pageData.altText: Equation 1: Mathematical equation for determining rate, where rate equals the change in the variable (e.g., temperature, pressure, or distance) divided by the change in time

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram
pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. To prepare, download Google Earth Pro and the Plate Tectonics Lab file. In Activity 1, open the file and observe the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. Next, observe the concentration of earthquakes. Then, measure the distance from Africa to South America. Next, calculate the rate of seafloor spreading. Then, compare the rate of sea floor spreading between Australia and Antarctica. Finally, observe the characteristics of types of plate boundaries. In Activity 2, print the map of plates and measure the length of the scale. Then, measure the distance across an anomaly and calculate its spreading rate. Repeat the last 2 steps for both plates on the map. Next, measure the distance to the furthest magnetic anomaly on the scale. Then, determine the age of the anomaly and calculate the spreading half rate. Next, calculate the total spreading rate. Repeat the last 4 steps for both ridges on the map. Then, continue to Activity 3.

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram (cont... )
pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for activity 3 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, you will print the elevation map. Then, you will measure the length of the scale. Next, you will measure the distance between volcanic centers. Then, you will calculate the rate of plate motion. Finally, repeat this activity until 4 different distances are measured.

pageData.content: Figure 19. The distribution of magnetic anomaly ages for two spreading ridges
pageData.altText: Figure 19: A map showing three lithospheric plates: Pacific plate, Cocos plate, and Nazca plate. The black double lines indicate the East Pacific Rise (EPR). The colored areas represent the paleomagnetic anomalies (“stripes”).

pageData.content: Figure 20. Elevation of the Hawaiian Islands
pageData.altText: Figure 20: Paleomagnetic data for the South Atlantic Ridge and East Pacific Rise. The diagrams show the distribution of crustal ages around two spreading ridges and the age of magnetic anomalies along with the age patterns on one side of each ridge axis

pageData.content: Figure 21. Elevation of the Hawaiian Islands
pageData.altText: Figure 21: Chart showing the Hawaiian hot spot track. The arrows indicate locations where basalt samples were collected for radiometric dating. The radiometric dates are provided in millions of years.

data.title: Δ
data.content: The mathematical representation of change

data.title: Absolute plate movement
data.content: The motion of a plate with respect to a fixed location

data.title: Active continental margin
data.content: A type of continental margin that is located on or adjacent to a plate boundary and features a narrow continental shelf and steep continental slope

data.title: Asthenosphere
data.content: A thin layer of pliable, plastically deforming rock in the upper mantle

data.title: Collision zone
data.content: A type of convergent margin in which two continents or island arcs have collided

data.title: Collisional mountain belt
data.content: A type of mountain formation created as an entire ocean closes and blocks of thick continental crust collide

data.title: Continental drift hypothesis
data.content: The hypothesis that the Earth's continents have moved over geologic time relative to each other, thus appearing to have "drifted" across the ocean bed

data.title: Continental margin
data.content: The location on a plate where the landmass (continent) meets the oceanic lithosphere

data.title: Continental rift
data.content: A location at which continental lithosphere is stretched and thinned to the breaking point

data.title: Continental volcanic arc
data.content: A chain of volcanoes that forms along the margin of a continent where oceanic crust subducts beneath continental crust

data.title: Convergent plate boundary
data.content: A type of plate boundary where the plates move towards each other and collide

data.title: Divergent plate boundary
data.content: A type of plate boundary where the plates move away from one another; this boundary type is found at the axis of submarine mountain ranges

data.title: Global mid-ocean ridge
data.content: A continuous range of underwater volcanoes that wraps around the globe like seams on a baseball stretching nearly 65,000 kilometers (40,390 miles)

data.title: Hot spot
data.content: A location within the mantle where rocks melt to generate magma and the resulting magma rises through the lithosphere to produce active volcanoes at the earth's surface

data.title: Lithosphere
data.content: The combined layer of crust and upper mantle rock

data.title: Lithospheric plate
data.content: A massive, irregularly shaped slab of solid rock generally composed of both continental and oceanic lithosphere

data.title: Mid-ocean ridge
data.content: A seafloor mountain system formed by plate tectonics

data.title: Negative anomaly
data.content: A reading of less than average magnetic field strength

data.title: Normal polarity
data.content: The type of Earth's magnetic polarity during which a magnetic compass needle points to the magnetic north pole

data.title: Oceanic trench
data.content: One of many very deep, narrow canyons along the rim of the Pacific Ocean basin

data.title: Paleomagnetic stripe
data.content: One of many alternating bands of positive and negative magnetic anomalies on the ocean floor

data.title: Paleomagnetism
data.content: Ancient magnetism recorded in rocks, sediment, or archeological materials

data.title: Passive continental margin
data.content: A type of continental margin that is far from a plate boundary and features a wide continental shelf and a gentle continental slope

data.title: Plate boundary
data.content: Where two lithospheric plates make contact

data.title: Plate tectonics
data.content: The scientific theory that explains the outer layer of Earth as a group of separate plates that move with respect to each other and change Earth’s surface as they move; also called plate-tectonic theory

data.title: Plate-tectonic theory
data.content: See plate tectonics

data.title: Positive anomaly
data.content: A reading that exceeds the average magnetic field strength

data.title: Relative movement
data.content: The movement between two plates at a given point on the plate boundary

data.title: Reversed polarity
data.content: The type of Earth's magnetic polarity during which a magnetic compass needle points to the magnetic south pole

data.title: Seafloor spreading
data.content: A geologic process in which tectonic plates split apart from each other

data.title: Subduction zone
data.content: A region in which a portion of a lithospheric plate sinks beneath another plate into the Earth's interior

data.title: Transform boundary
data.content: A type of plate boundary where two plates slide past one another along a vertical fracturing zone

data.title: Transform fault
data.content: The vertical fracturing zone along which two plates slide at a transform boundary

data.title: Trench
data.content: The boundary at a subduction zone

data.title: Triple junction
data.content: Where three lithospheric plates make contact

data.title: Velocity
data.content: Change in position divided by time

data.title: Volcanic island arc
data.content: A chain of volcanoes, hundreds to thousands of miles long, that forms above a subduction zone
